importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the most recent update on global efforts to strengthen early-warning systems for extreme weather, emphasizing urgency amid rising climate-related disasters.
The date references the glacier collapse in Switzerland in May 2025, which served as a real-world example of how early monitoring and alerts can save lives and prevent loss of property.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article highlights the current year, 2025, as a period of intensifying extreme weather events globally, including floods and wildfires, which underscores the urgency of implementing early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has reported that 90% of weather, water, and climate-related deaths in the past 50 years occurred in developing nations.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52 in the past decade), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is especially dire in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
Real-world examples, such as the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten in May 2025 due to a monitored glacier collapse, demonstrate the life-saving potential of early warnings.
No country is immune to climate change and extreme weather, as highlighted by Swiss officials during the UN conference.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) is urging global action to close critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather, citing that nearly half of all countries lack sufficient capacity, especially in developing nations. Over the past 50 years, more than 2 million people have died due to weather-related disasters, with 90% of those deaths occurring in developing countries. The WMO acknowledges progress, with 108 countries now using some form of early-warning systems, but highlights that half still have only basic or inadequate systems. Real-world examples like the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, in May 2025 due to a monitored glacier collapse, underscore the life-saving potential of such systems. The article emphasizes that extreme weather events are escalating globally—impacting countries such as Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, southern Europe, and the United States—proving that no region is immune to climate change and reinforcing the urgent need for equitable, science-based early-warning networks worldwide.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
